Package dk.dibs.android.library

DIBS Mobile Payment Library (DMPL) - Merchants and developers can use DMPL to add payment functionality to mobile apps.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
PaymentResultListener Client apps implement this to receive notifications from ongoing payment processing.
PaymentServerListener Client apps implement this to receive notifications about payment server availability.
 

Class Summary
DibsPayment View to present payment window in.
PaymentData Base class for generating payment window data.
PaymentServer Abstract the DIBS payment servers and the functionality to locate an "optimal" payment window URL.
PreAuthorizationPaymentData Represents the payment window parameters needed for the "pre-authorize" flow.
PreAuthPurchasePaymentData Represents the payment window parameters needed for the "pre-authorize and credit card payment" flow.
PurchasePaymentData Represents the payment window parameters needed for the "credit card payment" flow.
TicketPurchasePaymentData Represents the payment window parameters needed for the "ticket pay" flow.
 

Enum Summary
Theme Defines the possible layouts of the payment window.
 

Package dk.dibs.android.library Description

DIBS Mobile Payment Library (DMPL) - Merchants and developers can use DMPL to add payment functionality to mobile apps.

Merchants and developers can use DMPL to add payment functionality to mobile apps. The payment transaction is completely integrated into the app. Customers pay using DIBS without leaving the application.

NOTE: While you can download and integrate DMPL free of charge into your app, you will need an agreement with DIBS to be able to process payments.

Overview

For processing payments, DMPL loads a web view with a mobile specific payment window in it. Care has been taken to make this view look like the app platform, and there is a collection of themes to apply. The web view has been wrapped into an app platform specific class, which provides means to control the payment window and receive notifications from the payment process in a form, that suits the platform.

Configure Payment Servers and URLs

If nothing special is setup, DMPL will fallback on a default configuration for which payment servers to use and which payment window to show.

If you have specific needs, you can control this setup, through the PaymentServer class. 

   URL defaultServerBaseURL = new URL("https://pay1.dibspayment.com");
   String paymentWindowURLPath = "/mobilelib/?mobilelib=android";
   List<URL> failoverPaymentServers = new ArrayList<URL>();
   failoverPaymentServers.add(new URL("https://pay2.dibspayment.com"));

   PaymentServer.setupPaymentServers(defaultServerBaseURL, paymentWindowURLPath, failoverPaymentServers);
defaultServerBaseURL
This will be the default payment server to contact. If you provide failover servers and use the optimal payment server resolution feature, the payment window might use another base URL. If no optimal server has been determined when payment window is shown, this default server will be tried.
paymentWindowURLPath
Identifies which payment window to show. Contact DIBS to get the value that suits you.
failoverPaymentServers
Extra servers, that can be used in combination with the optimal payment server resolution feature.
In the case where you will need to perform this setup call yourself instead of relying on defaults, DIBS will provide you with the values you need in the call for servers and URL path.

Include Payment View in Layout

The DibsPayment class is a layout class itself, which makes it possible to add it directly into your layout.

Here is an example on how to add to your layout: 

  <dk.dibs.android.library.DibsPayment
        android:id="@+id/dibsPayment"
        android:layout_width="fill_parent"
        android:layout_height="fill_parent"/>

Working with the Payment View

The app using DMPL does not interact directly with the web view, but instead use the DibsPayment class. The DibsPayment class internally use a web view, to show the payment window and do the payment processing.

Here is code sample on how to display payment window for a "purchase with credit card" flow: 

public class TestAppActivity extends Activity implements PaymentResultListener {
    public void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
        super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
        setContentView(R.layout.main);

        PurchasePaymentData paymentData = new PurchasePaymentData("your-merchantId-here", "DKK", "id-of-your-order", 1250, PaymentData.PAYMENT_TYPES);
        // paymentData.setTest(true); // when testing
        paymentData.setTheme(Theme.ANDROID_NATIVE);
        paymentData.setCancelUrl(optionalCancelUrl);
        paymentData.setCallbackUrl(yourServerCallbackUrl);

        DibsPayment dp = (DibsPayment) findViewById(R.id.dibsPayment);

        // add your listener implementation class, to be notified about events in the payment flow
        dp.setPaymentResultListener(this);

        // initiate actually showing the payment window
        dp.loadPaymentWindow(paymentData);
    }

    public void paymentAccepted(Map<String, String> paymentData) {
    }

    public void paymentCancelled(Map<String, String> paymentData) {
    }

    public void errorOccurred(Map<String, String> errorInfo) {
    }

    public void paymentWindowLoaded() {
    }

    public void cancelUrlLoaded() {
    }

    public void failedLoadingPaymentWindow() {
    }
}
In short, the above code does the following:
  • Sets its content view (which includes a ref to DibsPayment)
  • Constructs a PaymentData subclass, that fits the requested payment flow and initializes it properly
  • Obtains the reference to DibsPayment
  • Sets the listener (here, itself) to receive notifications about payment processing
  • Initiates loading of payment window

Themes

The payment window supports many different pre-made designs and a unique custom design, where it's possible for the developer to set some user-specific Cascading Style Sheets (css). The theme is set in the paymentData with the use of 
paymentData.setTheme(Theme.ANDROID_NATIVE);

Standard themes:

The unique pre-made designs, which the payment library supports.
  • IPHONE_DIBS
  • IPHONE_NATIVE
  • ANDROID_DIBS
  • ANDROID_NATIVE

Custom theme:

  • CUSTOM
It's possible to set some custom CSS in the paymentdata, when the theme is set to custom 
paymentData.setTheme(Theme.CUSTOM);
. This is done by setting the customThemeCSS in the paymentdata. 
setCustomThemeCSS(String customThemeCSS)
The "customThemeCSS" string should be a JSON object, which describes the design parameters.

Available parameters

All the parameters are case-sensitive.
Parameter name Type Description
appBgColor Hex color code Sets the background color on the payment window
paybuttonBgColor Hex color code Sets the background color on the pay button in the payment window
paybuttonFontColor Hex color code Sets the font color on the pay button in the payment window

Example: {"appBgColor":"#BABA21","paybuttonBgColor":"#000000","paybuttonFontColor":"#FFFFFF"}

Receiving Notifications

Throughout the payment process, certain events and flow cycle announcements are sent to a listener. To receive these announcements in your app, you implement the PaymentResultListener interface and set as listener on the DibsPayment view. 
     public void paymentAccepted(Map<String, String> paymentData) {
         // Called if payment was accepted
         //
         // You can use this method to do stuff like hiding the view that was showing
         // the payment view and/or show some message to the user, call your backend, ...
     }

     public void paymentCancelled(Map<String, String> paymentData) {
         // Called if payment was cancelled
         //
         // You can use this method to do stuff like hiding the view that was showing
         // the payment view and/or show some message to the user, call your backend, ...
     }

     public void errorOccurred(Map<String, String> errorInfo) {
         // Called if an error occurs in the payment window.
         //
         // You should at least check the error number for critical errors and
         // dismiss payment if so. See class docs for further info.
     }

     public void paymentWindowLoaded() {
         // Called when payment window is fully loaded, and ready to accept user input
         //
         // You can use this method to hide any spinner or the likes, that you might have put up in front
         // while the payment view was loading.
     }

     public void cancelUrlLoaded() {
         // Called if cancel URL has been set, payment was cancelled, and the cancel URL loaded successfully
     }

     public void failedLoadingPaymentWindow() {
         // Called if payment window fails loading
     }
The above (empty) implementation of PaymentResultListener documents the supported methods and their possible uses.

Cancellation of Payment

The payment view supports cancellation of ongoing payment through the DibsPayment.cancelPayment() method. One way to use this, is to provide some kind of "cancel action" (button or something), shown together with the payment view, which if the user clicks this, calls the cancel method on the payment view.

You should not directly dismiss the payment view directly after calling DibsPayment.cancelPayment(), but instead wait for a callback to the listener. This will ensure the payment window gets time to "clean up" the ongoing payment process. How cancellation is done is determined by how far into the payment flow, the process has come:

Payment window has been loaded
When cancel method is triggered, the payment window will start cancelling the ongoing payment. As a part of that, any set cancel URL is loaded (which will trigger PaymentResultListener.cancelUrlLoaded()) When payment window is finished cancelling payment, a call to PaymentResultListener.paymentCancelled(java.util.Map) is made.
Payment window has not fully loaded yet
A call to PaymentResultListener.paymentCancelled(java.util.Map) is made.
It is up to the app using DMPL, if it want to use a cancel URL. It could just as easily do its own cancel processing in the PaymentResultListener.paymentCancelled(java.util.Map) callback.

MAC Security

Due to security restrictions, the library does not provide the MAC calculation functionality itself. The library does supports MAC security in the sense, that it is possible for the app to provide a pre-calculated MAC value in the payment form data PaymentData.setCalculatedMAC(String). If a MAC value is provided in the form data, it will be verified by DIBS, and the payment will be declined if incorrect or tampered with. Pre-calculating MAC values should be done by a server-side service on the merchant part, which the app needs to call prior to showing the payment window.

How to calculate MAC

In the mobile library you need to calculate the MAC on some different variables depending on the payment method. You can find the method in the following table:
iOS DIBSPurchase DIBSPreAuthPurchase DIBSPreAuthorization DIBSTicketPurchase
Method app_buy app_preauthandbuy app_preauth app_buywithticket
Below this you can see which variables are used in the calculation:
parameter \ method app_buy app_preauth app_buywithticket app_preauthandbuy Notes
merchant R R R R merchant identification
amount R   R R smallest unit
orderid R R R R merchant identifier for the order
currency R R R R as indicated in ISO4217
paytype R R   R comma separated list: DK,V-DK,MC,VISA,MTRO,DIN,AMEX,ELEC,JCB
ticket_id     R    
theme O O O O iphonenative,iphonedibs(DEFAULT),androidnative,androiddibs
timeout O O O O time in ms for the payment to be processed
lang O O O O da_DK, sv_SE, nb_NO, en_UK - default da_DK
callbackurl O O O O server2server callback
cancelurl O O O O autosubmit-to-cancelurl on cancel
uniqueoid O O O   flag orderid/customerid to be unique
test O O O O flag payment to be in test mode
MAC O O O O pre-calculated MAC value for tamper check
Calcfee O     O calculate the fee in the payment window and let the cardholder pay the fee
(R = required, O = optional) you should only add the optional parameters to the MAC calculation if you use it in the application. For the theme parameter value, use the table below to find the value:
Theme Value
Theme_iPhoneNative iphonenative
Theme_iPhonedibs iphonedibs
Theme_AndroidNative androidnative
Theme_AndroidDIBS androiddibs
Theme_Custom custom
The parameters:
  • calcfee
  • test
  • uniqueoid
Must be sent with the value "y" If you want to see the parameters which are sent to the payment window, you can get a list by calling: 
getPaymentWindowData() on your paymentData class.
Please remember, not all the parameters sent gained from this method should be calculated into the MAC. If you want some of your own custom parameters to be included in the MAC calculation, they should start with the "s_". For more information on how to calculate MAC see http://tech.dibs.dk/dibs_api/other_features/mac_calculation/ This documentation is for the Dibs Payment window, but the way to calculate the MAC key should be the same.

Ticket

If you wish to use Ticket payments i.e make it possible for a cardholder to pay without all the card information, or withdraw in subscription style, you need aa agreement with NETS/PBS and the "Abonnementspakke" at DIBS. There are two ways to create a ticket.
  • "DIBSPreAuthorization" is used to create a ticket on the cardholder's card. The Ticket created will be returned as the parameter "transact".
  • "DIBSPreAuthPurchase" is used to create a ticket and make a normal payment with the cardholder's card. The payment transaction number will be returned as "transact" and the ticket will be returned as "ticket".
After the ticket has been created, it's now possible to create "DIBSTicketPurchase" with the ticket returned from "DIBSPreAuthorization or DIBSPreAuthPurchase.

Demomode

By setting the merchant parameter to "demo", it's possible to start the payment window in demo mode. While the payment window is in demo mode, it reacts og looks like the normal paymentwindow, but the only cards accepted are DIBS test card found at http://tech.dibs.dk/10_step_guide/your_own_test/. All the payment errors are also supported, as described on the "your_own_test" page. It's also possible to try out the ticket system, by either creating a "DIBSPreAuthorization" or a "DIBSPreAuthPurchase", or by using the following formula: ticket = [card prefix]+1234
[card prefix] is found at the "your_own_test" page fx.
Cardtype Prefix Formula ticket
Dankort 5019 5019 + 1234 50191234
It's not possible to test MAC calculation in demo mode.

Possible Error codes

errorcode errormessage
-1 No initial data received from shop
0 Did not receive all arguments from shop, missing: [Parameter]
1 Payment could not be processed. Gateway is not accepted.
2 Platform does not support payment with registered card.
9 Missing required argument: [Parameter]
10 WARNING: Data has been tampered. Checksum is not valid.
11 Wrong value for parameter:[Parameter]

13 Selected language is not supported
14 Uniquid differs from orderid
18 merchant is not valid
19 This parameter is a DIBS reserved parameter:[Parameter]
20 An error occured during trying to fetch automatic card detect javascript from xml
32 Wrong merchant recieved from shop.
34 Currency is not valid
38 Orderid contains invalid characters.
39 HMAC checksum is not valid.
50 An agreement error occurred
51 Cardtype not supported
52 No agreement found for this cardtype/currency
53 Creditcard is not supported
99 WARNING: Data has been tampered, transaction will not be registered as accepted
100 Network communication error: [curl error]
110 Error in communication with DIBS, response code: [response code]
115 Error in response from gateway, missing argument:[Parameter]
120 Payment declined, reason: [Reason]
121 Payment can not be processed, no gateways available. Choose another payment type.
122 Your session has timed out.
666 WARNING! Data has been tampered, transaction will not be registered as accepted
1000 Rejected by acquirer.
1001 Communication problems.
1002 Error in the parameters sent to the DIBS server. An additional parameter called message is returned, with a value that may help identifying the error.
1003 Error at the acquirer.
1004 Credit card expired.
1005 Your shop does not support this credit card type, the credit card type could not be identified, or the credit card number was not modulus correct.
1006 Instant capture failed.
1007 The order number (orderid) is not unique.
1008 There number of amount parameters does not correspond to the number given in the split parameter.
1009 Control numbers (cvc) are missing.
1010 The credit card does not comply with the credit card type.
1011 Declined by DIBS Defender.
1020 Cancelled by user at 3D Secure authentication step.
2000 Enter card number
2001 Cardnumber invalid
2002 Cardnumber does not match \"Payment Card\"

2007 invalid year
